s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Inheritance, polymorphism, and parametric types are taught, as well as concepts such as boxing and auto boxing.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Apply basic algorithmic analysis to simple algorithms; use appropriate algorithmic approaches to solve problems (brute-force, divide-and-conquer, recursive backtracking, heuristic).

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Use, implement, and evaluate fundamental data structures and associated algorithms; create, implement, debug, and evaluate algorithms for solving substantial problems, including recursively, using divide-and-conquer, and via decomposition; implement an abstract data type.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: The Advanced version of this course covers these topics in more depth, allowing students to deepen their understanding and experience.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Distinguish language definition from implementation, syntax and parsing from semantics and evaluation, understand how program state maps to memory (globals, local, heap), and understand the implications of heap reachability for memory management.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: The important role of standard libraries and their collection types will be emphasized.  GUI programming will be introduced.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Students will be introduced to an industrial strength object oriented programming language, extending their understanding of the imperative programming paradigm with a solid grounding in object oriented programming.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Deliver and evaluate basic technical documents, presentations, and group interactions, using appropriate tools.

s2: Apply fundamental programming concepts, using an object oriented programming language, to solve substantial problems.

s2: The foundations of software engineering including: major development paradigms (such as big plan up front, agile, and formal methods), risk are introduced.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Major foci are data structures, object oriented programming, and an introduction to software engineering.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: The theory of data structures and their time and space complexity will thus be tied to the practice of using standard collections such as those offered by object oriented languages.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of software development with a substantial group software project at its center.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Students will extend their understanding of software productivity tools, using revision control for group work, and be introduced to test-driven development as an integral part of software construction.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: The course includes a deeper treatment of data structures, using hash tables, trees and lists, which are used to provide concrete implementations of abstract library collection types.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Develop, understand, test, and evolve substantial programs using a modern IDE, and associated configuration tools; understand common coding errors and how to avoid them; practice fundamental defensive programming; perform individual and team program reviews; use established design principles to organize a software system.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Understand the basics of event-driven programming, and its use in constructing GUIs

s1: The following topics are addressed: system programming and its facilities (including I/O, signals, job control, interprocess communication, sockets, transport layers, remote operations), system calls and their relation to the system libraries, process management and coordination, implementation of message passing, memory management, interrupt handling, real-time clocks, device-independent input/output, serial-line drivers, network communication, disk drivers, deadlock avoidance, scheduling paradigms, file systems, security.
s2: The Advanced version of this course covers these topics in more depth, allowing students to deepen their understanding and experience.

s2: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of software development with a substantial group software project at its center.

s2: Inheritance, polymorphism, and parametric types are taught, as well as concepts such as boxing and auto boxing.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: Distinguish language definition from implementation, syntax and parsing from semantics and evaluation, understand how program state maps to memory (globals, local, heap), and understand the implications of heap reachability for memory management.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: The Advanced version of this course covers these topics in more depth, allowing students to deepen their understanding and experience.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: Use, implement, and evaluate fundamental data structures and associated algorithms; create, implement, debug, and evaluate algorithms for solving substantial problems, including recursively, using divide-and-conquer, and via decomposition; implement an abstract data type.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: The important role of standard libraries and their collection types will be emphasized.  GUI programming will be introduced.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: The course includes a deeper treatment of data structures, using hash tables, trees and lists, which are used to provide concrete implementations of abstract library collection types.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: The theory of data structures and their time and space complexity will thus be tied to the practice of using standard collections such as those offered by object oriented languages.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: Students will be introduced to an industrial strength object oriented programming language, extending their understanding of the imperative programming paradigm with a solid grounding in object oriented programming.
